title: What are the disadvantages of having a basement? - Quora

response.answer_text: When we built our home 35 years ago, and our kids were in grade school, we built over half crawl space and half basement, finished. It was useful at times but not nearly enough to justify the extra cost (to us). Now that the kids are married and in their own homes the basement is largely unused — but not forgotten. Our furnace and water heater are down there, and our “dry basement" system which is reliant on a properly working sump pump. In all those years we have never had damaging water in the basement, but, we have to maintain the sump pump and have consider installing a second battery backup system. Not cheap. When the cheap plastic drier duct finally clogged up and leaked after 25 years, I couldn't simply and easily replace it without tearing up the finished drywall ceiling — not worth it. So I had to reroute the drier vent to the garage (next room over). Not the best alternative but the easiest and cheapest. We found out last year that having a dry finished basement does not increase the market value of the home appreciably. Looking back, I wish I never had the basement built. You have to decide what is of value to you.

If you asked my wife she’d say she’d never have a basement again. This is because it never stays dry whenever we get one of those toad strangler rain storms! It’s mainly due to having a concrete block foundation wall that has a broken seal at the point where it meets the slab. Even if you have a “dry” basement you still have a lot of humidity in it. That’s usually the case with any space that’s below ground. I think it’s because there’s a lot of moisture that’s trapped in the basement because there’s no windows to ventilate it. If you had a walk out basement (windows on one or more sides) that helps! Another problem that comes up with a basement is plumbing. Sometimes the Sewer Main is higher than the basement floor. If you wanted a bathroom in the basement you would have to have a grinder pump in order to get the sewage out of the building. If the pump goes out (wear or power outage) any plumbing down there couldn’t be used. If they were used they could back up into the basement. All that said a basement could be a great way to add more liveable space to your house, including a storm shelter and additional storage.
